comments.body: I'm not sure what the police for conda-forge is, but I have some problems with this. Especially if this is a dependency of other tools and you actually don't know about this restriction.

Conda-forge is not a commercial (or even a legal) entity, and so this restriction does not apply to us.  If someone takes the conda-forge package and redistributes it for commercial gain, they would be the ones in breech of the license, not conda-forge.

Also if someone redistributes the conda-forge package commercially, they were provided the license in the package telling them not to.  

I don't see any reason for conda-forge to not build this package nor any harm to conda-forge in doing so.

I think you are probably right. Though IANAL.

Would add that when I see non-standard license text like this, I kind of wish conda-forge did have some sort of legal counsel so they could review and advise.
@jakirkham - yeah that would be one benefit of having some sort of numfocus affiliation

I agree with everything that has been said so far:

1. This license is more restrictive than most users would expect. From my reading, even if the commercial product makes the source code openly available (e.g. as required by a copyleft style license), they still have to obtain permission first from ACM.
1. conda-forge is not violating the license because we are not including it in a commercial product, and we are including the license with the distributed binary.
1. The point of including the license information with the conda recipe and conda binary is so that end users can decide if the software license is appropriate for their use case.
1. Most end users are unlikely to check the licenses of every dependency (but also most users are not creating a commerical product, and those that are should seek legal counsel)
1. Unfortunately none of us our lawyers...

I investigated the packages that have akima as a dependency. There are 4 CRAN packages (DATforDCEMRI, FGN, RchivalTag, spikeSlabGAM), and although they don't state anything about the ACM license, they are all CC BY-NC-SA (i.e. non-commercial, so that is somewhat compliant).

There are 3 Bioconductor packages (LedPred, OCplus, splatter). These are much more troublesome. LedPred is MIT, OCplus is LGPL, and splatter is GPL3. From my understanding, all 3 packages are violating the terms of the ACM license by stating their packages are available under these open source licenses.
Does anyone else have an opinion on the license for this package? What is the process for making a final decision on a recipe with a non-standard license?
I think that this is probably OK to merge.  I'll be happy to do it if no one objects in the next 8 hrs
